awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Developmental Adaptation to High-Altitude Hypoxia
awd_abstract_narration:
High-altitude hypoxia, or low oxygen availability at high elevations, presents one of the strongest selective pressures in human evolutionary history. Despite this formidable environmental stressor, several human populations have thrived at high altitude for millennia and display unique adaptations to low oxygen availability. Although recent research has documented the role of genetic evolution in shaping different adaptations to high altitude, less is known concerning the role of epigenetics – or influences shaping gene expression – with respect to how different populations respond to the stressor of hypoxia. This doctoral dissertation research project investigates the extent to which high-altitude hypoxia impacts DNA methylation (DNAm – one specific kind of epigenetic effect) patterns in a human population, and the functional role that DNAm contributes to adaptation to this environment. In doing so, this project directly contributes to the body of knowledge on human evolution, variation, and adaptability by exploring the critical role of epigenetic change on high-altitude gene expression patterns and phenotypes. This project supports STEM-focused educational and outreach efforts in research and local communities, and training of undergraduate research assistants.

Using a migrant study design, this project analyzes epigenetic, transcriptomic, and phenotypic data from three groups of study participants with differential exposure to hypoxia. Differential methylation analysis between the three participant groups is used to identify differentially methylated positions and regions associated with developmental exposure to high-altitude hypoxia. In tandem, mRNA sequencing and analysis is used to identify gene expression patterns associated with exposure to high altitude. Association testing between DNAm levels and 1) gene expression and 2) adaptive phenotypes identifies key methylation differences associated with transcriptomic and phenotypic changes. This multi-omics approach offers new insight into the role of adaptive developmental plasticity in shaping human adaptation to high altitude. Further, results of this study build on on previous studies of DNAm patterns in other high-altitude populations. By comparing the role of epigenetic changes in shaping high-altitude adaptive phenotypes in different populations, this research provides critical insight into the convergent patterns of high-altitude adaptive phenotypes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
High-altitude hypoxia, or the low partial pressure and availability of oxygen at high altitudes (>2,500 meters above sea level), is one of the strongest environmental pressures experienced by modern humans. Despite the harshness of this extreme environment, several global populations including Andeans and Tibetans have thrived at high elevation for thousands of years, exhibiting a range of physiological and genomic adaptations that facilitate survival within this hypoxic environment. Among these high-altitude native populations, long-term exposure to high-altitude hypoxia has led to evolutionary adaptive change through the process of natural selection. Extensive genome-wide investigations have revealed genomic targets of positive natural selection that contribute to altitude-adaptive phenotypes. However, the role of epigenomic change in shaping altitude-adaptive variation, particularly among Himalayan populations, remains less understood.

This study was the first to investigate epigenetic changes associated with lifetime high-altitude exposure among Nepali Sherpa, a Tibetan population living today in the highlands of Nepal. We recruited study participants with varying levels of lifetime high-altitude exposure with either Sherpa or non-Sherpa ancestry over two seasons of field research in Nepal. This included: 1.) 64 high-altitude Sherpa (HAS) participants who were born, raised, and resided at high altitude in the Solukhumbu region of Eastern Nepal, 2.) low-altitude Sherpa (LAS, n=14) participants who were born, raised, and resided at low elevation in Kathmandu, Nepal (1,400m), 3.) high-altitude Nepali (HAN, n=14) participants with long-term, but not lifetime, high-altitude exposure, and 4.) low-altitude Nepali (LAN, n=14) participants who were born, raised, and resided in Kathmandu. In addition, we recruited two study groups of high-altitude trekkers, 14 low-altitude Sherpa and 14 low-altitude individuals of European ancestry who trekked together to high altitude at 4,300m.

We focused our analysis on the most widely studied and stable epigenetic mark, DNA methylation. We identified differentially methylated regions among high-altitude Sherpa compared to Sherpa residents of low altitude. In addition, we compared DNA methylation data for Nepali Sherpa to a second altitude-adapted population, Andean Quechua, resulting in two key findings. First, we observed population-specific plastic changes in circulating immune cell composition of natural killer cell, neutrophil, memory B, and memory CD4+T and CD8+T. We further identified correlations between circulating immune cell types with high-altitude adaptive phenotypes including forced expiratory lung volume and resting arterial oxygen saturation. Second, we found key methylation differences for hypoxia inducible factor (HIF) pathway genes, the central pathway involved in the body’s response to hypoxia. Our most compelling HIF finding demonstrated that Nepali Sherpa exhibited lower DNA methylation levels of EPAS1, a gene encoding the protein HIF-2α that is a central transcription factor of the HIF pathway, compared to Peruvian Quechua and Nepali Non-Sherpa. This reduction in DNA methylation suggests that EPAS1 expression may be upregulated resulting in greater activation of the HIF pathway in hypoxia. However, leveraging DNA methylation data with our RNA sequencing data, we identified evidence of differential transcript variant usage wherein individuals with lower methylation were more likely to express a nonfunctional EPAS1 protein isoform. This finding suggests that epigenetic changes among Nepali Sherpa at high altitude may in fact decrease EPAS1 HIF-2α production and augments existing DNA evidence that the Tibetan EPAS1 allele is a partial loss-of-function allele. Together our multi-omic findings begin to demonstrate how epigenetic changes are linked to phenotypic and transcriptomic consequences among Nepali Sherpa. They further suggest that population-specific mechanisms underlie the observed epigenetic differences between Himalayan and Andean populations, highlighting the distinct ways independently adapted populations may have responded to the same environmental pressure.

Broader impacts of this work focused on STEM outreach to elementary and middle school student in the Los Angeles area. Co-PI Zhu presented and facilitated webinars and hands-on presentations to local elementary and middle school students that focused on genetics and epigenetics. These presentations were designed in collaboration with teachers to complement existing curricula and build upon California Next Generation Science Standards. Co-PI Zhu also organized, facilitated, and created slides for interactive presentations whose aim was to give students hands-on experience with concepts in genomics and environmental sciences. Through these activities, students gained knowledge and familiarity and with these scientific topics, practiced hypothesis formulation and testing, and received encouragement to pursue STEM education and careers. This funding has supported the completion of a PhD dissertation for a graduate student in Biological Anthropology at UCLA. Two manuscripts describing these results are in preparation and are anticipated to be submitted for publication within a year of the funding end date, with additional manuscripts forthcoming.
